msDesc.head: Geoffrey of Monmouth,Historia regum Britanniae; Peter Langtoft, Metrical Chronicle (book 3) in Anglo-Norman; etc.

p.secFol: A vt a regibus; B brith Ly tierz.

supportDesc.support:
Written on 120 membrane leaves of average quality, preceded by two paper flyleaves of s. xviii and followed by two membrane flyleaves, s. xv or xvi, and two paper flyleaves, s. xviii. Originally two manuscripts, probably with a common origin, A, and B consisting of three separate sections Bi, Bii—vii, Bviii—ix.
Fore- and endleaves: fol. irv, blank; fol. iir, contents-list etc.; fol. iiv, blank; fol Irnote; fols. Iv-IIr, blank; fol. IIv, ex libris; fols. IIIr—IVv, blank.
supportDesc.collation: Collation: 18 210 3-58 610 7-88 98 (wants 8) || 108 (+ three (fols. 76-8) before 1, with stubs after 8, added to supplement quire 9) || 11-128 1310 || 148 No quire numbers or signatures. Contemporary catchword (by scribe?) on quire 3, and by 16th-century hand on additions in quires 9 and 100 (fols. 74v, 75v, 77v).
supportDesc.condition: Edges severely trimmed, with loss of marginalia.

layoutDesc.layout:
Written in one column throughout,
180-95 125 No prickings are visible. Ruled in crayon. Folded HSOS.

binding.p: Sewn on five bands between millboards covered with 18th-century blind-stamped and -ruled leather as on MSS 34 and 36 and similar to that on MS 197. Repaired by Maltby, May 1951 on pastedown.

history.provenance:
Written in NE England between 1303 and 1333 (see item B(ii)). Fol. IIv Liber Georgij Bromley ex dono patris sui charissimi Georgij Bromley militis Anno Domini 1586 regnante Elizabetha Pacifica. This isrepeated below less calligraphically. On fol. 1r Anno Domini .1587. .12°. die Aprilis. anno .29°. Reginæ Elizabethæ. circa horam 3am in aurora ex hac vita migrauit Thomas Bromley miles, Dominus Cancellarius Angliæ, et Regiæ maiestati ex intimis concilijs prudens, et in legibus Angliæ peritissimus, et ex cuius lingua melle dulcior fluebat oratio. On Thomas Bromley see DNB. The Bromleys were members of a distinguished legal family of Shropshire origin. The George Bromley miles mentioned above was probably the brother of Sir Thomas and Chief Justice of Chester, while the other George was probably his third son, of Shropshire, admitted to the Inner Temple in November 1585; see Students Admitted to the Inner Temple 1547-1660 (London, 1878), 113.
Nothing is known about how the book reached All Souls but a number of features that it has in common with MSS 34, 35, and 36 show that it shares part of its history with them (see under MS 34) and since they came to the College in 1768 (see under MS 35) MS 39 came, if not at the same time, presumably soon after. Pre-All Souls marks are a.19, 9.G.14, and His. Aug. 5 on the front pastedown, references to William Nicolson's Historical Library, evidently the London, 1736, edition, and a contents-list on fol. iir, and 16:3 (s. xvii?) on fol. 1r. All Souls library identifications, on which see Introduction, are, on the front pastedown, w.9.7 and vv:3:7 (both deleted), 86 (pencil), MS. 39 (figure added), L.R. 1.f.7 (pencil), and bookplate no. 9.

recordHist.source: Andrew G. Watson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts of All Souls College Oxford (Oxford, 1997)

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact library@all-souls.ox.ac.uk.

altIdentifier.idno: All Souls College MS. 39, part A

msItem.incipit: Fol. 1r Incipiunt historic Regum britannie que nunc dicuntur Angli Cum mecum multa et de multis [...] interno congratulatur affectu. Britannia insularum optima
msItem.explicit: Fol. 78r in latinum sermonem transferri curaui. Explicit.
msItem.author: Geoffrey of Monmouth
msItem.title: Historia regum Britanniae

listBibl.bibl: Ed. as MS 35 above. This manuscript is described by J. C. Crick, The Historia regum Britannia of Geoffrey of Monmouth iii: A Summary Catalogue of the Manuscripts (Cambridge, 1989), 216-18.

msItem.note: There are no book divisions. The text was left unfinished; fol. 74v/17 to fol. 78r is a completion in a 16th-century italic hand, from ei rex Salomon (Faral, iii. 295/1; Griscom, 524/2; Hammer, 201/1-2) to the end. Fol. 78v is blank.

handDesc.handNote: By one scribe, in anglicana formata with punctuation by low and high point and punctus elevatus.
Additions on fol. 74v/17-78r are in a good though not carefully written italic of s. xvi.

decoDesc.decoNote: Two- and three-line red and blue lombards, flourished in the other colour, with guide letters, also sometimes plain capitals (all are plain from fol. 53v onwards).

history.provenance: Marginalia of ss. xiv (crayon) and xv (ink).

altIdentifier.idno: All Souls College MS. 39, part B

msItem.incipit: Fol. 79r Iadis al tens des Engleys soleyt Engletere estre en cinkes partyes
msItem.explicit: Fol. 86r Apres ly fu Roy Edward son fiz ke conquist Gales et Escoce.
msItem.title: An account of the Saxon and Norman kings to Edward I, in Anglo-Norman.

listBibl.bibl: For manuscripts containing other versions of the same text and an edn. of that in CUL, MS Ee.i.i, see D. B. Tyson, 'An Early French Prose History of the Kings of England', Romania, 96 (1975), 1-26.
Noted by Hardy, Cat., iii, no. 327;
J. Vising, Anglo-Norman Language & Literature (Oxford, 1923), no. 374.

msItem.incipit: Fol. 87r Ki voet oyr de Rays coment chescon vesquist
msItem.explicit: Fol. 103v For he has ouer hipped His tipetes es tipped. His tabard es tome.
msItem.author: Peter Langtoft
msItem.title: Chronicle

listBibl.bibl: Ed. J. C. Thiolier, Édition critique et commentée de Pierre de Langtoft Le Règne d'Édouard (Paris, 1989), who describes our manuscript (S) at 121-4.;
ed. T. Wright, The Chronicle of Pierre de Langtoft, 2 vols. (RS 47; London, 1866-8), ii. 162/1-258/15 (1272 to mid-1296).
Noted by Vising, Anglo-Norman Language, no. 377.

msItem.note: It is one of twenty-two manuscripts of Langtoft, eighteen of which contain Le Règne, and is a text of the second redaction, one of four manuscripts plus a fragment of the a group. Judging by the dialect, the manuscript was written in NE England (Thiolier, 125) and can be dated on textual grounds to 1303 X 1333. For four verses in English inserted into the Anglo-Norman text (some slightly misread by Thiolier) see IMEV and Supplement: for fol. 100v/1-4 IMEV 2754; fol. 101v/24-5 IMEV2686; fol. 102r/24-7 IMEV3352; fol. 102v/24-5 IMEV841.

msItem.incipit: Fol. 104r Hec sunt staciones quas statuit beatus Gregorius. In primis omnibus ad sanctum Petrum venientibus .vij. anni relaxantur. vota fracta. si ad ea redierint. peccata oblita offensa patrum et matrum sine mannum [sic] inieccione
msItem.explicit: Fol. 105v Dominica post pascha ad sanctum pancracium .iij. ann' .iij. quadrag' .xl.d. Summa Indulgenciarum .CC.lij: Ann' .lxx.d.
msItem.incipit: Fol. 106r Omnibus christi fidelibus cognoscere desiderantibus que uel quante sint indulgencie que a beato Gregorio papa primo sunt in Romana vrbe ad salutem anime institute per presentes
msItem.explicit: Fol. 107v quarta pars omnium scelerum relaxatur et durat Indulgencia per viij dies.
msItem.title: List of 110 indulgence grants at the stationes of the city of Rome, followed by a later pope's quotation of the relevant indulgence of Pope Gregory I.

listBibl.bibl: Spurious: see N. Paulus, Geschichte des Ablasses im Mittelalter, ii (Paderborn, 1923), 296.

msItem.incipit: Fol. 107r Primus Normannus dux Rollo qui et Robertus dictus est regnauit in Anglia .xxxa. annos
msItem.explicit: Fol. 109r et genuit ex ea filios Edwardum et Edmundum et filias.
msItem.title: Genealogy of English kings from Rollo of Normandy to Richard I of England (1189-99).

listBibl.bibl: See Hardy, Cat., ii, no. 366, for other copies, none extending later than Stephen (1135-54).

msItem.incipit: Fol. 109v Anno domini .mo. cc. octogesimo nono. Passio ministrorum domini Edwardi Regis Anglie secundum opera sua. Edwardus Rex quidam nobilis abiit in regionem longinquam accipere sibi tributum
msItem.title: Narratio de passion justiciariorum

listBibl.bibl: Ed. T. F. Tout and H. Johnstone, State Trials of the Reign of Edward the First 1289-1293 Camden Society Third Series 9, 1906), 5-9, using BL, MS Add. 31826 (MS A) and our manuscript (MS B), which, they suggest, may derive from an untraced common original.
Also ed. by P. Lehmann, Die Parodie im Mittelalter, 2nd edn. (Stuttgart, 1963), 199-202, who records selected variants from a third text, BL, MS Harley 2851, fols. 148v-50v.

msItem.incipit: Fol. 111r Peractis a natiuitate domini .cccc. et Nonaginta quinque ann'. Kerdikes regnauit .xv. annos
msItem.title: Regnal years from the kings of Wessex to Stephen (1135-54)

msItem.incipit: Fol. 111v Anglia habet in longitudine occies .C. miliare
msItem.explicit: Fol. 112r in veteribus scriptis eorum inuenitur.
msItem.title: An account of the shires and bishoprics of England and Wales.

msItem.incipit: Fol. 113r Sanctissimo in christo patri domino .B. diuina prouidentia sacrosancte Romane ac uniuersalis ecclesie summa pontifici. Edwardus dei gracia Rex Anglie etc. [...] Infra scripta non in forma nec in figura iudicij.
msItem.explicit: Fol. 117v per tempore diuturna. Dat' apud Notelham .viij. die maij. Anno gracie .mo. ccco. primo. et regni nostri vicesimo .ixo.
msItem.title: A letter from Edward I to Pope Boniface VIII, concerning the king of England's rights to the realm of Scotland.

listBibl.bibl: Ed., with translation, from London, PRO, Close Rolls (C 54), 118, membs.
10 d 9 d (C), E. L. G. Stones, Anglo-Scottish Relations 1174-1328 (Oxford, 1965), 192-218, q.v. for other copies and editions.

msItem.incipit: Fol. 117v Memorandum quod anno domini .mo. ccco. tercio. circa festum Natiuitatis beate marie contigit casus qui subscribitur de Bonifacio papa[...] Ecce reuerende pater.
msItem.explicit: Fol. 120v in tam modico tempore sicut nos hic vidimus. Dat' Rome die ueneris proxima ante festum sancti michaelis. Anno domini supradicto.
msItem.title: Account by William Hundleby of an attack on Pope Boniface VIII at Anagni in 1303.

listBibl.bibl: Ed. and tr. H. G. J. Beck, 'William Hundleby's Account of the Anagni Outrage', Catholic Historical Review, 32 (1947), 190-220.
W. Holtzmann, 'Zum Attentat von Anagni', Festschrift Albert Brackmann (Weimar, 1931), 492-507, gives a collation of our manuscript with the text in MGH Scriptores xxviii. 622-6.

handDesc.handNote: By one scribe, in anglicana, with punctuation by medial and low point.

decoDesc.decoNote: Two/four-line plain red initials, with guide letters.
Some beginnings of verse lines are touched with red and there is some red underlining.
